Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wood Fiber Reinforced Polymers using Ring-Opening Polymers for Structural Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this collaborative research project will be on the effectiveness of wood fibers to reinforce alternative plastics. A long-standing goal for research on natural-fiber composites has been to replace glass-fiber, reinforced plastics with natural-fiber composites. Natural fibers have excellent mechanical properties and should be able to replace glass-fiber applications in the built environment with a more sustainable material. Unfortunately, the transformation to natural fibers has been slow, in part due to an overemphasis of prior work on "exotic" fibers and on reinforcement of incompatible plastics. Wood fibers are being combined with a polyamide matrix, which has excellent mechanical properties and is likely to be compatible with wood fibers. The composites will be made via ring-opening polymerization of novel oligomeric cyclic amides. This approach avoids the high temperatures in polymer processing that can damage natural fibers. The composites will be characterized for mechanical and interfacial properties. Wood fibers are readily available in commercial wood pulp products. The effect of pulping process on composite properties will be evaluated. All wood-fiber composites will be compared to glass-fiber controls to verify their suitability as a replacement material.

Global demand for glass-fiber, reinforced plastics is increasing, but those products are neither renewable nor sustainable. The development of wood-fiber, reinforced plastics will define a new, cost-effective, sustainable, bio-composite material. The deployment of wood-fiber, reinforced plastics would involve collaborations between the wood pulping and the plastics industries. Although the wood pulping industry is larger than the glass fibers industry, it is currently in decline. The introduction of wood-fiber, reinforced plastics could impact the future of this declining US industry and could impact society by providing more sustainable materials. The novel processing methods developed may also lead to new opportunities for using engineering polymers with bio-based materials. This project will train two graduate students in sustainable materials development. Oregon State University has recently transformed its undergraduate curriculum for wood science and engineering department into a "Renewable Materials Program." This project will involve undergraduate researchers, which will enhance an emerging program on sustainable materials. Oregon has many underrepresented forestry students and Southern Mississippi has a sizable minority student population. These students will benefit from training in the broad area of sustainable materials engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the use of wood fibers (or other reinforment materials dervied from wood) to reinforce polymers to provide high-performance composite materials. The use of natural and sustainable materials, such as wood, can lead to more environmentally-friendly building products. Two composite-science questions that arise when working with wood are: 1. How well does wood interact with polymer matrices, or, in other words, what are the properties of the wood fiber/polymer interface? 2. Once wood, polymer, and interfacial properties are known, how can one predict the expected properties than can be achieved in wood fiber/polymer composites? This second question is key to composite material development. A thorough understanding of the range in properties that can be expected is a crucial tool in development of new products. Such tools are especially vital when embarking on new materials types such as natrual fiber composites.

The modeling work focused on new theories for predicting stress transfer between the fiber and the matrix though an imperfect interfaces. The analysis used an "optimal shear lag" method that was developed previous by the PI. This new model accounts for fiber and matrix properties, fiber length, interface effects, and stress transfer at fiber ends. The method was validated by comparison to finite element analysis and to prior theories. The model is claimed to be the current model with the most accuracy and most capabilties.

A novel finite element techique was developed to test the theory for more complicated composites and for a wide range in fiber and matrix properties. The new finite element analysis revealed new insights about short fiber composites with soft matrices, such as nanocomposites made with rubbery polymers. By coupling the shear lag model with the finite element analysis, a new analytical model was developed that can predict composite properties for composites with rubbery matrices. It may be the first model to cover such a wide range in fiber and matrix properties.

Two new methods were developed to characterize the interface in short fiber composites. Both are inverse methods. One method back calculates interface properties from composite mechanical properties (using the new modeling methods). The second method is more direct. It observes strain fields on a specimen surface near an embedded fiber and then couples those experiments with 3D computation mechanics to evaluate the properties of the fiber/matrix interface. This second method achieves the same results that have been done in the past using Raman spectroscopy. Those Raman methods, however, only work for a few fibers types and for transparent matrices. Our new methods work for any fiber type (our interest was in wood fibers and experiments were done with wood particles) and can work for opaque matrices.

In summary, the new modeling methods that account for interfacial properties combined with experimental methods to measure interfacial properties may provide valuable tools for development of new composite materials. The tools will be most valuable for developing composite products derived from noval materials such as wood fibers, other natural fibers, cellulose nanocrystals, carbon nanotubes, or other nanofillers combined with a wide range of polymeric matrices,

 

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2016
Modified by: John A Nairn
